subject: Re: How many aspects a particular test method should test???

messageBody:
That is 1 or 2 , not 1 & 2. Hence the control would definitely go to
someParam++. But as Chris pointed out, update to someParam would
evaporate as soon as someMethod has stopped execution.
Doesn't matter to me what the method is precisely doing. All I wanted
to know was whether for each IF-ELSE, loops , and other constructs in
a method , should we be writing a separate method OR one that takes
care of 'em all.

Thanks for the reply. Keep pouring in more though. As I am still not
quite clear on this issue.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@c... wrote:
> Yep,...I would go for two methods as well.
>
> If you truly want to test the IF clause, then you also need to test
with a few different params being passed in.
>
> From that testing, I think you may find that this method doesn't
work as intended,...or I'm not reading the logic correctly. The way I
read it, you will always throw the exception, because you can never
get the state where someParam equals 1 and 2. [If someParam doesn't
equal 1, then throw exception,...if it does equal 1, check to see if
it doesn't equal 2, then throw exception,...if 1 equals 2, then
increment someParam.]
>
> Please let me know if my logic is correct,...or where I have failed.
>
> -------------- Original message --------------
> Personally, I'd probably write two test methods.
>
> But my advice is to try it both ways and then see
> which one "smells" better. Does one approach
> look like
>
> ARRANGE
> ACT
> ASSERT
>
> ARRANGE
> ACT
> ASSERT
>
> while the other looks more like
>
> ARRANGE
> ACT
> ASSERT
> ACT
> ASSERT
>
> ?
>
> And if so, which one feels best to you?
>
>
> Todd.
>

> > Hi all,
> > I am really really new with JUnit. Do excuse me if this
> > question is too simple that it irritated you. OK so here is
> > my confusion:
> >
> > The method I want to test is something like this:
> >
> > public void someMethod(int someParam) throws invalidParamException {
> > if(someParam!=1||someParam!=2)
> > throw invalidParamException
> >
> > someParam++;
> > }
> >
> > Now this method will test someParam passed to it and if it
> > gets stuck in the IF statement will throw exception else
> > update someParam. Now what I wanna know is that the test
> > method that I write to test a method like this should I be
> > writing one test method that tests both whether exception is
> > thrown correctly as well as someParam updated correctly. OR I
> > should be writing one test method that tests for the
> > exception and another that tests whether someParam is being
> > updated appropriately.
> >
> > Please reply soon.
> >
> > Thanks.
